title: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument: Fossils
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Nature     Natural Features & Ecosystems     Fossils                 Fossils         Sheep Rock and the John Day River NPS photo, Chris Schierup  Welcome to the Cenozoic, the Age of Mammals...  “No region in the world shows a more complete sequence of Tertiary land populations, both plant and animal than the John Day Basin.” - Dr. Ralph W. Chaney  Preserved within the assemblages of the John Day Basin is a fossil record that spans over 40 million years. If each time period recorded here is a page in a book, the National Monument holds an entire chapter of Earth’s history which tells the story of changing life and landscapes.  Please use the following links to explore each of the fossil bearing assemblages of the John Day Basin and imagine how much life has changed in the past 50 million years.               Clarno Assemblage (44 Ma)             Hancock Mammal Quarry (40 Ma)             Bridge Creek Flora Assemblage (33 Ma)             Turtle Cove Assemblage (29 Ma)              Upper John Day Assemblage (24 - 20 Ma)              Mascall Assemblage (15 Ma)            Rattlesnake Assemblage (7 Ma)
